  Hey, very sorry about the confusion and thanks for your patience!

We originally didn't allow queries against external data sources from FnordMetric Server by default. The reasoning behind this was that both CSV and MySQL expose access to the local file system and we didn't want to enable that by default for security considerations. 

Since this is obviously a gotcha, we decided to change it. If you pull the latest version of FnordMetric from Github and recompile, you will be able to execute queries against MySQL and CSV files from FnordMetric Server by default. This does not require any additional command line flags.

For example, start FnordMetric Server like this:

```
mkdir -p /tmp/fnordmetric-data
fnordmetric-server --http_port 8080 --datadir /tmp/fnordmetric-data
```

You can then execute queries against MySQL, e.g.:

```
IMPORT TABLE test_table
  FROM 'mysql://localhost/test_database?user=root';

SELECT * FROM test_table;
```

To revert to the old behaviour and disable external data sources, start FnordMetric Server
with the `--disable_external_sources` flag. For example:

```
fnordmetric-server --http_port 8080 --datadir /tmp/fnordmetric-data --disable_external_sources
```

Many thanks for your support and contributions to FnordMetric.
  FnordMetric Server currently only supports reading data from MySQL. To execute a query against a MySQL database you can check out this page in the documentation:

  http://fnordmetric.io/documentation/chartsql/external_data_sources/

You can see a simple example here:

  https://github.com/paulasmuth/fnordmetric/blob/master/fnordmetric-doc/examples/queries/mysql_backend.sql

Note that the naming of the IMPORT Statement might be a bit misleading. It doesn't actually "import" or copy any data. The query will be pushed down into the MySQL server and the charts will be rendered from the query result that is returned by the MySQL server.

Does this answer your question?

Many thanks for your support and contributions to FnordMetric.

 Added instructions for running FnordMetric Server via Docker to the documentation: http://fnordmetric.io/documentation/installation/

To run FnordMetric Server using docker:

```
$ sudo mkdir -p /var/lib/fnordmetric-data
$ sudo docker run -p 8080:8080 -p 8125:8125/udp -v /var/lib/fnordmetric-data:/data/fnordmetric -t fnordmetric/fnordmetric-server
```

To build a Docker Image for FnordMetric Server, use the included dockerfile:

```
$ git clone https://github.com/paulasmuth/fnordmetric.git && cd fnordmetric
$ sudo docker -t myrepo/fnordmetric-server build .
```

  Hey,

Question 1: The Postgres backend is not implemented yet but is on our roadmap. Expect an update on that in the next weeks.

Question 2: The name of the IMPORT statement is a bit misleading. The IMPORT statement only creates a "virtual table", it doesn't actually copy any data. As much of the query as possible is pushed down into MySQL/the external data source and the charts will be generated from the query result that is returned by the external data source. So I think the IMPORT statement already does what you're asking for.

Many thanks for your support and contributions to FnordMetric.

  Yes, as bernd pointed out you can either just set the _time field, or use the included importer:

If you usually run your fnordmetric app like this:

```
ruby my_fnordmetric_app.rb run
```

you can also invoke the "import" task like this:

```
ruby my_fnordmetric_app.rb import DUMP_FILE=/path/to/newline_seperated_events.json
```

If you use "progressive/persistent gauges" (any of your gauges has the :progressive => true option) the events in the dump_file need to be in chronological order (first line should be the oldest and last line should be the most recent).

Btw, there is a third task called "log" which you can use to create these log/dumpfiles:

```
ruby my_fnordmetric_app.rb log DUMP_FILE=/path/to/events_19.01.12.json
```

 to set the username and picture send these events to fm
 -> you don't need to define any event handlers
 -> the session token (_session) could be your unique session id 
    or the unique user id (it's hashed)

```
# set the user name
{ "_type": "_set_name", "name": "Tingle Tangle Bob", "_session": "mysessiontoken" }

# set the user picture
{ "_type": "_set_picture", "url": "http:#myhost/123.jpg", "_session": "mysessiontoken" }
```

if you want to count action/events unique per session you can 
set up an event handler like this:

```
gauge :myaction_uniqe, 
  :tick => 1.day.to_i, 
  :unique => true

event :myaction do
  incr :myaction_uniqe
end
```

and send events like this one:
    { "_type": "myaction", "_session": "mysesstiontoken" }

the gauge will only be incremented once per session token (and tick/interval)
so this gauge would show "daily unique myactions"

if you want e.g. the average body size of all users on a given day:

```
gauge :average_body_size, 
  :tick => 1.day.to_i, 
  :unique => true,
  :average => true

event :user_body_info do
  incr :average_body_size, data[:body_size]
end

# events:
{ "_type": "user_body_info", "body_size": 186, "_session": "userid_1" }
{ "_type": "user_body_info", "body_size": 162, "_session": "userid_2" }
{ "_type": "user_body_info", "body_size": 173, "_session": "userid_3" }
```

  Mh, timezones shouldn't be an issue, since the function which converts the unix (utc) timestamps to a human readable date runs on the client side / in your browser. 

The reason all history events display 08:00:00 as creation time is a bug though: When fnordmetric queries the history events from the "timeline set" it doesn't fetch their creation dates for performance reasons right now (they are stored in another set). So the 08:00:00 is really just a zero timestamp. I guess we should either remove the date from the list if we don't have it or actually fetch it from redis. What do you think? 
  This (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xqd4qwON6bY) is how people around here pronounce it. The video is german, but the original text is english - in case you're also wondering what fnord is :) http://www.fnord.org/occult/discordia/text/what.is.fnord 
  The received_events counter gets incremented when an event is sent via tcp or http-post. It means, that the event has been picked up and appended to the internal event queue. 

The processed_events counter gets incremented when the event is popped from that queue and actually processed in (one of) the worker(s).

  Hey, sorry for the late answer. The "oops, lost an event" message is actually a bit misleading right now. It means, that an event-id was popped from the queue but no hash with the accompanying "#{prefix}-event-#{event_id}" key was found. 

After a restart this may be cause by expired data - Incoming events have a ttl of 2 minutes per default (see opts[:event_queue_ttl]).

  Provides a UDP inbound server with backwards compatibility to the TCP server.

To enable the UDP server:

``` ruby
FnordMetric.server_configuration = {
  :inbound_protocol => :udp,
  :inbound_stream => ['0.0.0.0', '1339']
  # other options omitted
}
```

Since the UDP message boundaries are respected by the EventMachine datagram socket ([doc](http://eventmachine.rubyforge.org/EventMachine.html#M000480)), FnordMetric::InboundDatagram#receive_data does not need to build a message buffer as is necessary in FnordMetric::InboundStream#receive_data.

Also checkout my client gem to send events to FnordMetric from Rails/Sinatra etc over UDP: [fnord-client](https://github.com/rossta/fnord-client) 

Credit to [knewter](https://github.com/knewter) for his original UDP server [pull request](https://github.com/paulasmuth/fnordmetric/pull/59)

  This pull request is not intended to just be merged without thought, but I thought I might as well start discussion around the UDP server (rather than TCP).  I would anticipate that this would be a huge request for many people, because TCP is not fire and forget and this way my app that sends data to fnord has no requirements on redis, and sending my data causes no real performance hit (with TCP I have to wait for ack, etc).

This is related to the following issue: https://github.com/paulasmuth/fnordmetric/issues/20
## Anticipated points of contention

I would anticipate that you still desire the ability to offer the TCP server for backwards compatibility reasons (though in fairness, I definitely think it is the Wrong Sort of Thing for this kind of app).  My code rips it out entirely, but if you want to provide configuration support for choosing one or the other, just give me some pointers on what you want to see and I'll gladly provide it.

Can we get a discussion started around this?  I'm going to be using my fork starting today, but I would prefer it be merged if it's good with you.  Thanks again for fnord!

Well, so I want to give a little help, so I just found a little bug, and I fixed that.

The problem is that when we are using a progressive gauge, it's only set a value in a tick when some event triggers some change. But when a tick is skipped, not having any change, it doesn't change the value stored at Redis hash.

My solution is keep record of what is the last tick in a key that can be accessed by that can be obtained by some_gauge.key(:head_tick), if some_gauge.value_at is called on a tick that has an undefined value and is greater than head_tick, value_at method returns the value stored at some_gauge.key(:head).

Same thing happens when calling some_gauge.values_in.

But doing only this, there is a problem that, if a tick is skipped, and after that the next tick is set, the missing tick remains undefined, so a timeline widget has a wrong 0 value at that missing tick.

To avoid this behavior, I modified the incr_tick method at GaugeModifiers, so now, when a new head_tick is created, new code looks for missing ticks between last head tick, and the new one, setting them as the last head value, so when some_gauge.values_in or  some_gauge.value_at looks for those ticks, they are already defined with the right value.

  Fixes some issues with execution flow jumping back and forth between EM reactor and EM non reactor threads.

Should prevent issues like #37 in the future.
 Why should it be faster?

EM has by default 1 reactor thread and a pool with 20 'side threads'.

At line https://github.com/paulasmuth/fnordmetric/blob/master/lib/fnordmetric/worker.rb#L35 we delegate whole event processing to 'side thread'. It is perfect as events can be processed in parallel. 

However, whenever non blocking redis call is invoked, processing goes back to reactor thread. We experienced it in issue #37 . Things got really messed there.

In my opinion the design where events are taken from the queue in reactor thread and are processed in 'side threads' (without coming back to reactor thread) is much simplier and cleaner.

Other solution would be to process everything in one reactor thread (don't use defer) at all.

  The example code from the Readme for submitting events has a race condition.

``` ruby
redis.lpush("fnordmetric-queue", uuid) 
redis.set("fnordmetric-event-#{my_uuid}", event)
redis.expire("fnordmetric-event-#{my_uuid}", 60)
```

I assume the receiving side does a (blocking) lPop. Following order of events can happen:
1. Client does lPush on the queue
2. Server does blPop on the queue
3. Server does Get on the key (fails, not found)
4. Client does Set on the key
5. Client does Expire on the key

To prevent the race condition the code needs to be re-ordered to

``` ruby
redis.set("fnordmetric-event-#{my_uuid}", event)
redis.expire("fnordmetric-event-#{my_uuid}", 60)
redis.lpush("fnordmetric-queue", uuid) 
```

to guarantee that any Get on the key that was Pop'd from the queue will succeed unless the key already expired.
Alternatively one could pipe the commands on the client so they are executed in one atomic step in Redis which will also save roundtrip times.
Additionally you can combine the Set and Expire into a single SETEX call.

  Hi,

FnordMetric is a nice application, but it has a license issue: [highcharts license](http://shop.highsoft.com/highcharts.html). It contains non-commercial license which is known to be not compatible with OpenSource licenses, including the MIT license.

There are some ways to fix this issue:
- use another JS lib for charting (probably not easy, but if you want to go in this direction, sooner is better)
- remove the highcharts from your repository and add to the README how to download it from its official website (with explanations of why you do that)
- contact the highcarts author...

I hope it helps.
